text:
The presentation I'm
going to give you today is a presentation I
give to law faculties.

It was my job talk paper. It is to law students
and people who think

about these in legal terms. And a theme of the
presentation is that the way that lawyers
think about these things

aren't accurate or are
somewhat misleading. And so a lot of what I'm
going to say to you--

I swear I'm not just
repurposing a talk and just-- that will not at all be
interesting or relevant to you.

But a lot of what
I'm saying is, here's how the systems actually work. That will be like bread
and butter to you. That'll be like, well, duh.

But maybe you'll be interested
in understanding why-- how lawyers think
about it and why

the language and the
frameworks that we come from when we
approach these issues-- and why there is some
disconnect between those

two frames of reference and
why this could be a problem

and why we need to find a way to
walk across campus, so to speak. So the paper, the presentation,
is "Content Moderation

As Systems Thinking." I'm just going to chuck
up a definition for how I'm thinking about
content moderation

for the rest of this talk, which
is they're system-- platform systems and rules
that determine how

they treat user-generated
content on their services. Now, we could have long debates
about this definition, I'm sure.

Yes, it is about how platforms
design their systems.

And it's also pretty broad. And that's going to be important
for the theme of my talk because this is a
lot broader than how

a lot of lawyers,
regulators, and policymakers

think about content moderation. And the argument that
I make in this paper

is that there's been this first
wave of content moderation institutional design, both
in platforms and in policy,

and that we need to think
about replacing that with a second wave. But before we get to
that argument, let's

talk about what
the first wave was. So the first wave relies on
this standard picture of content

moderation within platforms. And the way that people think
about content moderation in this framework
is that there's

an executive at the platform. And they sit above the rest
of the company, one of which--

one part of which is the
content moderation policy team, the people that sit
there and think really hard about speech rules
and think, oh, this

is where we want to draw
the line on hate speech. And that policy
team is completely separate from the
rest of the company,

including product growth,
engineers, government relations

teams, the people
that work on ads. There's just this
nice little group of speech philosophers
sitting off in the corner,

thinking about how do we
get these things right. And then they sit above
this massive bureaucracy

in the platform that has a whole
system of front-line content

moderators that are
dispersed around the globe and that assisted by artificial
intelligence tools that

make the first content
moderation decision. And if you're not happy with
the decision that you get there, you can appeal it up
certain number of tiers.

And so this is how
content moderation is thought of in this imagination.

And when I give this
talk to lawyers, I say, this should look really familiar
to you, this kind of picture,

because this picture of how
content moderation works is a pretty good analog for how
we think about offline speech

adjudication, and when I
talk about it in America, First Amendment adjudication. But other legal systems
around the world--

you have a decision
made against you. And if you're not happy,
you can go to court. And if you're not happy
with what the court says, you can appeal it up. And then ultimately,
you might end up

at the Supreme Court of the
United States or whatever. And the reason why
this picture has been so dominant
and persuasive has

been because a lot of these
systems and a lot of the writing that has been done about
this in the literature that policymakers and
things are reading,

and also the way that these
systems have been constructed within platforms,
has been by lawyers.

And when lawyers
see speech, they think of these judicial-esque
hierarchies for thinking

about these things. And so when we're thinking about
how to reform and how to make

content moderation "better,"
the key mode of error correction and accountability if you think
about content moderation in that

form is very individualistic--
what happened in this individual case to an individual
piece of content--

and its ex post, what happened
to an individual piece of content? And how do we fix the treatment
of that individual decision

after the fact? And for lawyers, when you're
thinking in those terms,

you think about process
being really good. We lawyers love process. And so if the problem
with this system

is we need more due
process for users, we need to give
them more reasoning, we need to give them more say
in the decision-- and the more

process, the better, the more
opportunity to appeal and things

like that-- that the better
this system is going to work. Now, the problem with
this-- and again, this

may just be totally
old yawn news to you. But when I present this to
people that are thinking about

this in policymaking terms,
this is mind-blowing for them-- is that during the time
that I'm speaking today,

Facebook's going to take
down over 700 pieces of-- 700,000 pieces of
content, not 700.

Even that, though, would
be difficult for lawyers to deal with. YouTube's going to take
down nearly a quarter

of a million pieces
of content, Tiktok-- 35,000 videos. And this Facebook
Oversight Board thing,

which we're going to come
back to later that operates as this Supreme
Court-style thing, is going to receive
107 petitions

to review Meta's decisions. That doesn't include
a whole bunch

of other kinds of decisions. That's only takedowns. That doesn't involve
decisions where someone's flagged a piece of
content in Meta or YouTube

decides to leave it up and
all the other kinds of content moderation decisions
that we might think of,

such as flagging--
sorry, such as labeling or down ranking or fact
checking or anything like that.

So this is only a small subset. In its entire history, the
entire history of the Supreme

Court, it has decided around
246 First Amendment cases.

So that's a pretty
different way of thinking. And the point is that it's
a different kind of problem.

When you have that
kind of scale, you can't use old systems for
thinking about these problems.

So we need to think about
content moderation not as just-- not just as a bigger version
of the problem that we have.

The scale shift is
so different that we need to think about it
completely differently. We need to think about it more
as a system, which means instead

of thinking about it in
these rights-based terms, like here is my speech
and here's the rule and here is my claim,
we need to think of it

much more as a regulatory
system and system design.

So the reason why this argument
is important is because this

judicial-esque model has really
been quite dominant in the way that a lot of lawyers and legal
academics have been talking

about it-- that we talk about content
moderators acting in a capacity very similar to judges.

We talk about the need
for a kind of digital constitutionalism for thinking
about this in much more

rights-based, speech-based-- speech rights terms. In civil society, the
policy prescriptions

that come up a lot
of the time are about adding more human
review to individual decisions

by having users provide
more information, having more reasoning,
having more appeals

that can more effectively
review individual cases. And this has then flown
through to a lot of regulation.
So this is a bill from--

this is a bill in Congress. The PACT act is one example
that has similar prescriptions

that the PACT Act would require
platforms to notify every time-- notify a user every time a
decision is taken against them,

give them an opportunity to
appeal, and give them reasoning. Similarly, there's bills
in Texas and Florida

that have done the same thing. Now, those cases--
we're going to come back to those at the end
to flag them for you.

They are going to head up to the
Supreme Court in the next year, most likely.

We can talk more about
that if that's of interest. But these bills in
Texas and Florida-- they're currently on ice. So the platforms don't have
to comply with them yet,

but potentially could. They have all of these
same prescriptions in them. The obligation of
the platform if they

have to comply
with these laws is that every time they
remove a piece of content, they have to notify--

provide an appeal, provide a
reason for the determination

every single time. And that's because this
picture of content moderation is what they're thinking
about when they're thinking

about how to reform it. And similarly in
the European Union, and this is coming down the--
this is passed and going to come

into force-- this is
not a hypothetical-- the European Union will
require big platforms

to provide a
statement of reasons every time that they take a
content moderation decision,

have an internal
complaint handling system that is open for
at least six months

after a decision is made that
a user can use to contest

the decision, six months. If a decision is
made about your--

if the platform thinks that your
picture of an onion is boobs and you have to have a right
to appeal that decision five

months later, it seems this
is a really quite burdensome procedural requirement
on platforms

that might not necessarily
result in significant benefits.

And then on top of
that, the platform also has to provide
for you to be able to appeal your decision
to an outside third-party,

independent third-party arbiter. So really extensive-- really,
what I want to underline to you

is this is really
right-- the idea here is that every individual piece
of speech is so important

that we need to think about it
in these really individualistic terms. Now, I think that
this picture, thinking

about content
moderation in this way, is blind to all of
the different ways

that content moderation
decisions get made that are outside of that
bureaucracy within a platform.

And the ex ante
systemic design choices and trade-offs
that affect speech,

how speech moves through
the platforms-- i.e., it's blind to a
lot of the thinking that all of you
in this room spend a lot of time doing about
how do we design this system

to be to be healthier
in the first place rather than fix up the
mistakes at the end.

And so in terms of
heterogeneity of institutions involved in content moderation,
this part of content moderation

is just a very small
part of how platforms think about designing
their systems to make

their environments-- enforce their rules and make
their environments healthier, as you all know.

So even within a
single platform, you have behavioral
content moderation that

falls outside that picture. So you have groups looking
for influence operations that are not focused on
individual pieces of content,

but are focused on how a
group behaves as a whole. So you're not going to see
those kinds of patterns

if you're only looking
at individual pieces. You have government
relations teams that have their own perspectives
on how speech decisions should

get made. And you have product
design teams, the people that
are deciding where

to put the like button
and the share tools and all of the interventions
that might affect how speech

moves through a
platform that aren't those individual decisions
about a piece of content. And then you also have people
outside the platform making

decisions, too. So we're increasingly seeing
content moderation decisions

delegated to outside
third parties-- so for example,
fact-checking organizations or authoritative
institutions, some

of the most prominent
being, for example, the World Health Organization
policy was imported into platforms' content
moderation decisions

during the pandemic. We also have users increasingly
involved and empowered

in content moderation
decisions who don't-- their decisions aren't really
seen in the bureaucracy.

And so much of the regulation
that we see coming down the pipe for thinking about
how to regulate content moderation and
platforms are blind

to community-based moderation. The mismatch between those
two is really obvious.

We also have governments who
interact with platforms and--

in different ways, both
formally and informally, to affect content moderation. And increasingly, we
have other platforms.

So we're increasingly seeing
much more collaboration across the industry,
both big and small, in terms of technology sharing,
database sharing, information

sharing that means that if
you are looking downstream at the end decision and
you're only thinking

about that decision,
you're going to miss where exactly the actor,
necessarily, that was actually

responsible for that
decision in the first place. So the main point here from this
very busy, very amateurly drawn

slide is that if you're
thinking only about that point, you're missing a whole
lot of the system.

And I'm not going to spend too
long on this because you all know this far better than I.
But if you're thinking only

about that bureaucracy and
those kinds of individual rule and the individual
piece of content, you're missing all of
the systemic design

choices that are involved
in doing content moderation.

So one of the big ones is when
you're operating at that scale, you have to acknowledge--

excuse me-- in a way that the
legal system doesn't that you are going to get things wrong. You are going to make mistakes.

You are just not going to make
700,000 decisions correctly every hour.

And so you have to-- whether it's the confidence
threshold on the tools

that you use or whatever
it is, whether you change the way that you think
about writing your rules

so that it's blunter
and maybe overbroad because you want to apply a
simple rule in a large amount

of cases, you have to make these
choices about false positives and false negatives in a
way that we don't really think about in a First
Amendment context

or an international
human rights law context, where we're thinking
really particularly about those individual
facts where a court will

look at an individual
speech act for eight months and then come out to an outcome. It's not really that same
problem of error tolerance.

We've already talked about how
platforms have to think about how much of the rules
are they going to enforce

and how much of it are they
going to leave for their users to enforce and moderate
themselves in a way that

is a system design choice that
isn't visible if you're only looking at that bureaucracy--

super curious for some of
your thoughts about this. I have been deeply
skeptical in my work

about the overall benefits
of always providing users a--

procedural justice in
such extensive ways in every case because
if you are loading

on lots and lots of
procedure and due process,

there are costs to that. There are costs to efficiency,
getting things done quickly,
which can be really important. There are costs, too-- and we can talk about--

more about this in a minute. But there's not
necessarily evidence or there isn't always
evidence that decisions

are more correct the more
times that they're reviewed. It might just be
that the people that

complain the loudest
and the longest get their content
reviewed more often. And so there's these
real trade-offs,

as well, that get
made in thinking about how to design
a system that I that I'm not confident
that this piling

on all these extra
procedures is necessarily going to target the exact
problems that we have.

And this is tied into
this idea of consistent versus contextual
decision-making. So you also have to
think-- if you're a Meta

and you are operating in
Brazil and the US and Myanmar

and Germany, you have a choice
to make about do you have a rule that you apply consistently
that a user can have--

post the same piece
of content and will get the same result in
each context regardless of social context?

And that will feel,
in a sense, just. But it also could
feel extremely unjust because you might have
different social norms

and different political
environment, completely different context. And so how does justice play
into those kinds of choices

when you're operating
at the scale that these platforms operate? And I am, as I should have
said at the beginning--

but is now really thinking
about the big platforms that many of the
regulations are targeted at.

The reason why this appeal
system, this individual ex post

review system, isn't
necessarily going to be effective at identifying
problems with content moderation

is that individual
errors are going to be poor vehicles for
identifying systemic failures. So they may be a canary
in the coal mine.

But it's not enough to just
find an individual error. It might be that that error is
a reasonable, rational result

of an error choice
made further upstream. On the other hand,
it could be evidence

of systemic bias within the
platform that is carried out.

And if you are just reviewing
that individual decision, you're not going to see
those systemic issues, nor are you going to fix
them because if you just

fix that one time that-- as we know, for
example, Black users

suffer disproportionate harm
under hate speech algorithms, or there's been research showing
hate speech algorithms that many

of these major platforms use. If you just fix
them one by one, you are not going to be fixing
the upstream problem of system

design that's
causing that problem. It's resulting in-- this
picture of content moderation

is also resulting
in mandates that are going to be
transparency theater, where it's requiring
platforms to produce a whole bunch of reports about
how many aggregate decisions did

you make in this particular
period that is what platforms

already do and actually reveal
very little about what's going on on the platform. They're great for producing
slides for slideshows that

tell you how many pieces
of content a platform will take down in an hour. But I don't know how much
you say unnecessarily

for doing anything
deeper than that. And we've already talked
about the process theater

that some of these
mandates can result in where uses get more
process, but don't necessarily

result in greater justice
across the platform overall. I'm just going to go
through this really quickly.

The transparency
theater is what I was saying-- that
because it's focusing on these decisions
in the bureaucracy,

a lot of the
transparency mandates that lawmakers in Congress,
in the States, in the EU

are requiring is figures about
how many pieces of content did you take down in
this three-month period.

And Facebook is really in
favor of this regulation. It said, yes, regulate us. And yes, make us do-- comply with that
because it already

produces those kinds of reports
and it would not be very costly. And it would be much more
costly for other platforms

to have to comply with
this kind of regulation.

These reports are
relatively uninformative.

They don't tell you the
accuracy of the figures that are presented. They don't tell you if a
platform is taking down

50% more of that kind
of content in a period, is that because they
changed their algorithm?

Is it because users
posted more hate speech? What is the reason
for that increase?

And that is not clear from
the face of the report. And it also might lead to
content moderation inflation,

where there is an incentive
at the moment, I think, for platforms to say,
we are taking down ever more pieces of content.

Look how good a job we're doing. We caught 1 billion
spam accounts. And that might have perverse
incentives on how platforms
think about content moderation.

Process theater-- talked
about this briefly,

about the costs of doing
all of that extra process.

Do want to be clear
that I don't think it's not the fact that I
think that all process should be should be gotten rid of.

I think it just needs
to be thought about much more carefully about what
is the goal that you're trying to achieve with extra process.

And are you actually
going to be achieving that outcome, which is not what
these regulations are targeted

at? So it may be very well the
case that in hate speech, for example, the kinds
of errors that are made

are the kinds that will be much
more easily identified or better

identified and fixed through
an extensive appeals process

through reasoning, through
explaining why I said something and getting reasoning back. That might not necessarily
be true for adult nudity,

for example, where the appeals
process might be much less useful. In terms of individuals
that use appeals

are not necessarily
representative-- so this is a information from
the Meta Oversight Board's

transparency report. And so it can hear appeals from
users who are unsatisfied with

their decision taken
on any of Meta's-- or on Facebook or Instagram.

And those top
lines-- the pink line is the number of
times users appealed if they had their
content taken down

and they wanted it
to be put back up. And that bottom line you
can't-- you almost can't see it because it's so close
to the zero line--

is the number of times people
appealed when they saw a piece of content that they
thought should-- broke the rules and they
thought it should be taken down.

Now, there's a huge gap. And there is no reason
that we necessarily

know of to think
that Meta is much, much better at
identifying takedowns,
that it's taking down content-- you know what I mean.

There's no reason
to think that Meta is getting one
decision right much more often than it is getting
the other decision right.

Why might we see that disparity? Well, because the user
whose content is taken down is much more invested. And they have to
appeal three times.

And they're like, I
got the wrong decision. I'm going to appeal it. They've got the wrong decision. I'm going to appeal again. And then they've got the
wrong-- and they're just

going to keep appealing because
they really want their post back on the platform. Someone who sees someone
else's post and they think, well, that
breaks the rules, and then they have to
go through the process

again and maybe provide more
reasoning-- at some point, they're probably going to
go, I don't care that much. And so using an appeal system
isn't necessarily going to fix--

isn't necessarily going to be
a representative way of fixing systemic problems, either.

So the argument that
I make in the paper is that we need to stop thinking
about this so much from an ex post fixing things behind--

after the fact to thinking
much more about system design choices, which I hope
many of you in this room

are in favor of, and
instead of thinking in individualistic terms,
thinking about it much more in terms of systems and
going from rights-based thinking

to much more regulatory
thinking, which is-- brings us to that argument that
I was making on the first slide

about moving from this
first wave of thinking about regulation to
moving to a second wave.

That looks much more in two
different buckets of reforms than the-- imposing all of these
procedural appeals mechanisms,

which may not be applicable
for every kind of platform, thinking much more about
structural measures

and more systemic
procedural measures rather than individualistic.

So structurally, I'm
interested in thinking about separation of functions.

What I mean by--
well, I'll come back to what I mean by that--
complaints mechanisms, disclosures of third-party
decision-making,

and retention of and
provision for access to data-- so separation
of functions. What I mean by
this is, in part, I

mean one of the biggest concerns
that we have in platform content moderation
decision-making and system

design is that it is not
that there are biases

in the way that the
system is designed or the decision-makers-- and
we have, for example, evidence to believe that people who are
involved in government relations

come in and step
in after the fact into content
moderation decisions and change them even though the
decision was taken in accordance

with the platform's rules. So I think separation
of functions eliminates the
incentives that makes

biased conduct
possible by hiving off those people from the
possibility of interfering in decisions.

And so to the extent
that decisions are made, there should be no capacity for
people outside that structure

to interfere with it. I think a complaints
mechanism for whistleblowing

would be useful for identifying
systemic failures that aren't going to be apparent
from the aggregate--

from looking at
individual cases. To the extent that outside
contacts are involved

in decision-making,
I think that this is, in particular as a
free speech scholar,

thinking about how governments
influence decisions-- I think is one of the things
that I would really to see--

is much more transparency about
the way in which platforms interact with
governments, but also with each other and the way in
which data sharing, database

sharing, things like that
happens across platforms so that we can actually identify
the source of the decisions

that are getting made
so that we can hold the correct actors accountable.

Retention of and provision
for access to data is not, I think, complicated
to understand

why that would be helpful. Otherwise, we are looking
at these individual cases

and trying to come up with
conspiracy theories for what's happening on a platform without
actually understanding things in the bigger picture.

Procedural
requirements-- I'm not

going to spend too long on this.  I think the kind of content
moderation governance and system

that I'm much more interested in
is forward-looking and thinking about risk assessments, thinking
about what are the possible

failure modes for-- yes? [INAUDIBLE] separation
of functions-- Oh, sure.

Great. So the way I understood
you saying it was that you want the
content moderation

to be separate from other
areas of the company because you don't want
them to influence. How do you square that
with engineers needing also

to consider this
content moderation? How do you weigh this
idea of influence versus just even them having to
work together, then be the same?

It's a great
question, and it's-- because you're right. There is an inconsistency
in what I'm saying. And so it's good to clarify.

On one hand, I'm
saying we need to think of this much more as a
system and all of the product design choices are
influencing how we

think about content moderation. On the other hand, I'm
saying to the extent that there are content
moderation decisions made, I want them to be
hived off from people

that have contrary incentives. So what I mean by
that-- this is a-- is that once content
moderation decisions are made,

they should not be interfered
with with other parts of the company. So for example, I think it is
relevant to have product growth

teams in the room describing the
incentives that they're building into the platform and the values
that the platform is reflecting

when you're thinking about how
do you think about the rules. But to the extent that
their incentives do not align with the unbiased
application of the rules

once those decisions have
been made as a way of ensuring that decisions
are both unbiased,

and also perceived
to be unbiased, is by ensuring
that they can't be

interfered with after the
fact by people outside that.

And it's important
because I'm not saying let's abolish
the appeal system. Maybe some of what
I've been saying might have sounded that,
which is not what I'm saying.

What I'm saying is that
we need to design it in a way that is much
more attentive to when is it beneficial and
when is it not beneficial.

And that is not the way that
these systems are currently being designed, which is
mostly, I think, performative.

So thinking about this-- much more interested
in accepting that there is going
to be system failure

and trying to identify where
the systems failures are on an ongoing basis through
auditing and quality assurance measures and thinking
about things much

more at a big-picture level
with continuous improvement rather than focusing on
individual mistakes--

happy to talk about that more. The one thing that I
wonder is that if I'd only

done this presentation three
years ago, no, I don't think it would have made
any difference at all. But we are seeing a lot
of regulations and things

coming down the
pipe that are really based on this first model.

I've talked about the
EU Digital Services Act. I've talked about Texas
and Florida's laws. India is also establishing these
grievance appellate committees

where you can appeal a system
up to a government-appointed appeals body.

Those are only some
individual examples. We've also seen this
model implemented

in the form of the Meta
Oversight Board, which I'm also happy to talk about much more. I've thought and written
about it quite a bit.

But one of the reasons why
I think its impact and its potential is been-- is limited
is because it really is based

on this individualistic model
of reviewing individual cases, and at a static point in time
after a decision has been made,

rather than thinking
about, maybe this-- let's look at a big
group of pieces of cases

and think about
what the system is doing to come up
with those outcomes and then, on a
continual basis, see how we can reform that
instead of just, well, put

this piece of content
back up and think about changing your hate
speech rule a lot of the time.

So as someone that was somewhat
optimistic about the Supreme Court when it first
was announced in 2018--

instead of being
a Supreme Court, is it of more like the DMV? Instead of revolutionizing
online speech,

is it going to marginally maybe
improve it just a little bit? So I've really had my
expectations tempered on that one because I think
it reflects this much more

juridical model. And I'm also happy
to talk about this. I don't know how interesting
it is for audiences, but--

for you. But there are a bunch-- this
is a really live legal issue, really, really live.

And there are a number of
cases on the Supreme Court's docket this term
and next term that

are deciding how the law
should treat these systems. Gonzalez and Taamneh are
going to be argued on the 21st

and 22nd of February. It's very exciting. And the Supreme Court is going
to be thinking about how to--

should platforms be
liable for the ways in which they amplify content? And one of the things that I
think is informing this case--

happy to talk about it more-- is that a lot of the way
that the law and lawyers

and potentially judges think
about content moderation and amplification is there's
an individual piece of content

that the platform is picking
up and recommending to someone and saying, hey,
watch this video.

And so if you're thinking
about it like that, it makes sense that,
yes, maybe the platform should be liable for
picking and saying,

watch this terrorism video. But if you step back and
understand it much more as a system, that
decision and drawing

the line between system
design and liability becomes a lot more complicated.

I won't go into the
other cases except to say that the Netchoice cases
there that I've put up there--

those are the ones arising out
of the Texas and Florida laws that we talked about
that impose all of these procedural
obligations on platforms.
